One of the targets for viral replication are kidney tissues. Some histological studies in non-human primates indicate that acute kidney tubular necrosis with protein cylinders and hemoglobin cylinders has some similarities with some classic histopathological findings of yellow fever in humans
30 . Maciel et al .
36 described in details the kidney lesions observed in the autopsy of patients affected by the severe form of yellow fever virus infection, which was associated to disseminated mycoses. In addition, according to the study by Maciel et al .
36 , interstitial nephritis was identified, associated with tubular necrosis and interlobular thrombosis in kidney vessels, as well as hemorrhage and ischemic necrosis of the adrenal gland.
